title: 113_hr1437
content:
The Act is titled the "Honorable Stephanie Tubbs Jones College Fire Prevention Act" and includes definitions for clarity. The Act defines an "approved fire suppression system" as meeting applicable codes and standards, ensuring safety for students with disabilities, and including features like automatic sprinklers, fire alarms, and mass communication systems for emergencies. The term "institution of higher education" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965, and the term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Education. Establishment of the Honorable Stephanie Tubbs Jones Fire Suppression Demonstration Incentive Program. The Secretary will establish a demonstration program to award grants for installing fire suppression systems in student housing. Eligible entities include institutions of higher education and tax-exempt social fraternities or sororities. The Secretary will prioritize eligible entities with the greatest financial need when awarding grants for fire suppression systems in student housing. Additionally, a minimum of 10 percent of the grant amount will be awarded to eligible institutions under specific sections of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary will prioritize eligible entities with the greatest financial need when awarding grants for fire suppression systems in student housing. A minimum of 10 percent of the grant amount will be awarded to social fraternities and sororities under specific sections of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary will develop a plan to inform eligible entities about grant opportunities, and if there are not enough qualified applicants, the remaining funds will be available for other eligible entities to apply. Eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary to seek a grant under this section. The entity must submit an application to the Secretary with required information. A non-Federal matching fund of at least 50% is needed for grant receipt. Funds should supplement, not replace, other fire safety funds. Administrative expenses are limited to 2% of the grant. Reports are required annually after the first grant award. The Secretary will provide Congress with an annual report on the grant program, detailing the number and types of entities receiving assistance, the amount of funding received, non-Federal funding leveraged, student housing equipped with fire suppression technologies, types of technologies installed, and relevant financial information. Authorization of Appropriations: The Secretary is authorized to appropriate necessary funds for the fiscal years 2014 through 2016 to carry out the program aimed at improving fire safety in student housing. The report to Congress will also include any identified policy obstacles to the development of fire suppression technologies. SEC. 4. ADMISSIBILITY AS EVIDENCE.

Notwithstanding other laws, applications for assistance under this Act, negative determinations by the Secretary, or reasons for such determinations cannot be used as evidence in any legal proceedings. An exception is made for using these documents as evidence in enforcing agreements between the Secretary and eligible entities.
